column1: Morayfield is a town and suburb of Moreton Bay Region
column3: Australia. It is 44 kilometres (27 mi) north of Brisbane CBD
column4: the state capital. In the 2016 census

column1: Morayfield is a mostly residential area
column2: consisting mainly of low-set brick homes and some semi-rural acreage. The main commercial area is concentrated along Morayfield Road and includes the Morayfield Shopping Centre
column3: which opened in 1997. The suburb is situated in the Burpengary Creek catchment area.

column1: The Bruce Highway passes from south to north through the suburb.
In 1868 Brisbane man George Raff bought some of the land held by the failed Caboolture Cotton Company
column3: derived from Raff's native Morayshire in Scotland. It was often written as "Morayfields" and
column5: became "Morayfield".Caboolture State School opened in present-day Morayfield on 4 August 1873. In 1890 it was renamed Caboolture South State School and in 1908 it was renamed Morayfield State School. (The present Caboolture State School in Caboolture originally opened in 1889 and was then known as Caboolture North State School).Morayfield State High School opened on 27 January 1981.Until the mid-1980s
column6: Morayfield remained a rural area consisting of a small dairy holding and small crop farming enterprises. However
column7: with the population pressure caused by the rapid growth of the greater Brisbane area
column8: it has since suffered to some degree from random or unplanned residential development and rapid population growth. It is a thriving retail and service industry commercial center.

column1: Morayfield East State School opened on 29 January 1991.Minimbah State School opened on 28 January 1997.In January 2011 parts of Morayfield were flooded during the 2010-2011 Queensland floods.
Morayfield has a number of heritage-listed sites
68 Captain Whish Avenue: Oaklands Sugar Mill

column4: 51.5% female and 48.5% male. The median age of the Morayfield population was 32 years
column5: 6 years below the national median of 38. 77.2% of people living in Morayfield were born in Australia. The other top responses for country of birth were New Zealand 5.5%
column9: Papua New Guinea 0.5%. 88.2% of people spoke only English at home; the next most common languages were Samoan 0.8%

column1: Morayfield State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at 196-230 Morayfield Road (27.1065°S 152.9472°E﻿ / -27.1065; 152.9472﻿ (Morayfield State School)). In 2017
column2: the school had an enrolment of 554 students with 46 teachers (44 full-time equivalent) and 33 non-teaching staff (23 full-time equivalent). It includes a special education program.Minimbah State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at the corner Walkers Road and Minimbah Drive (27.1107°S 152.9243°E﻿ / -27.1107; 152.9243﻿ (Minimbah State School)). In 2017
column3: the school had an enrolment of 802 students with 57 teachers (51 full-time equivalent) and 29 non-teaching staff (18 full-time equivalent). It includes a special education program.Morayfield East State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at 107 Graham Road (27.1168°S 152.9669°E﻿ / -27.1168; 152.9669﻿ (Morayfield East State School)). In 2017
column4: the school had an enrolment of 918 students with 64 teachers (58 full-time equivalent) and 47 non-teaching staff (31 full-time equivalent). It includes a special education program.Morayfield State High School is a government secondary (7-12) school for boys and girls at Visentin Road (27.1090°S 152.9533°E﻿ / -27.1090; 152.9533﻿ (Morayfield State High School)). In 2017
column5: the school had an enrolment of 1425 students with 115 teachers (112 full-time equivalent) and 48 non-teaching staff (36 full-time equivalent). It includes a special education program.Carmichael College is a private primary and secondary (Prep-12) school for boys and girls at 793-833 Oakey Flat Road (27.1729°S 152.9185°E﻿ / -27.1729; 152.9185﻿ (Carmichael College)). In 2017
column6: the school had an enrolment of 158 students with 16 teachers (14 full-time equivalent) and 6 non-teaching staff (3 full-time equivalent).

column1: Morayfield railway station provides access to regular Queensland Rail City network services to Brisbane and Ipswich
column2: as well as Caboolture and the Sunshine Coast. Morayfield Road is a major road that passes through both Morayfield and Caboolture
column3: most of the regions shops are situated on this major road
